qas.question: When was the People's Republic of China founded?
What has been promoted as the standard language of communication throughout China since 1949?
A majority of the population educated since what year can speak Mandarin?
What type of residents tend to be more fluent in Mandarin than rural ones?
Throughout history there have been a series of what in the area to allow for better communication?
When was the People's Republic of China defunct?
What has been not promoted as the standard language of communication throughout China since 1949?
A minority of the population educated since what year can speak Mandarin?
What type of residents tend to be less fluent in Mandarin than rural ones?
Throughout history there have been a series of what in the area to allow for worse communication?

context: Throughout history there have been a series of <a4_0><b9_0>lingua francas<b9_0/><a4_0/> in the area to allow for better communication. The dialects spoken in Hangzhou, Shaoxing, and Ningbo have taken on this role historically. Since the founding of the People's Republic of China in <a0_0><b5_0>1949<b5_0/><a0_0/>, <a1_0><b6_0>Mandarin<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which is not mutually intelligible with any of the local dialects, has been promoted as the standard language of communication throughout China. As a result, most of the population now can, to some degree, speak and comprehend Mandarin and can code-switch when necessary. A majority of the population educated since <a2_0><b7_0>1978<b7_0/><a2_0/> can speak Mandarin. <a3_0><b8_0>Urban<b8_0/><a3_0/> residents tend to be more fluent in Mandarin than rural people. Nevertheless, a Zhejiang accent is detectable in almost everyone from the area communicating in Mandarin, and the home dialect remains an important part of the everyday lives and cultural identities of most Zhejiang residents.
